bioghist.p: Richard Bartlett Gregg (1885-1974) was a social philosopher said to be America's first major theorist of militant nonviolence. His theories influenced Martin Luther King, Jr. and civil-rights theorist Bayard Rustin. Gregg traveled to India in the 1920s to seek out Gandhi and learn about the Indian independence movement. His publications include Gandhiji's Satyagraha or Non-violent Resistance (1930) and The Power of Non-violence (1934). He also wrote The Value of Voluntary Simplicity (1936).

scopecontent.p: The collection contains documentation related to civil disobedience in India, 1930-1933. Materials include: letters to Gregg from Mira Behn (Madeleine Slade) reporting on her activities and those of Gandhi; letters from Gandhi, Nehru, Roger Baldwin, Pyarelal Nair, and others; letters from Gregg to Gandhi, Roger Baldwin, P. J. Nehru, and The Nation magazine; weekly reports from India, summarizing Government acts and speeches, arrests, and civil disobedience actions; reports related to the May 1932 Bombay riots; bulletins from the India League and the International Committee for India describing events in the country; and copies of the Bombay Congress Bulletin and the Bombay University Bulletin.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
